moves.1. e4 e5 2. Bc4: Played mostly to avoid the Petroff.
moves.2... Nf6 3. d3 Nc6 4. Nf3 Be7: The Hungarian Defense. Somewhat passive, but solid.
moves.5. O-O O-O 6. Bb3 d6 7. c3 Na5: Similar to the Chigorin Defense to the Ruy Lopez, but White is a couple of tempi up since Black hasn't played ...a6 and ...b5.
moves.8. Bc2 c5 9. a3: White intends to gain space on the Queenside with b5.  Note this wouldn't work in the Ruy Lopez where Black has played ...a6 and ....b5.
moves.9... Nc6 10. b4 a6: 10..cxb4 11.axb4! would increase White's control of the center and activate the a1-rook.
moves.11. h3: 12. Nbd2 is the most common move in this position, but Triviakov has another idea.
moves.11... Re8 12. Re1 Bf8 13. Be3: This why White played h3 and delayed Nbd2.  This move applies pressure against c5.  Bg5 comes into consideration.
moves.13... cxb4 14. axb4 b5 15. Nbd2 Bb7: To discourage White from playing d4.
moves.16. Bg5: Now that the tension on the b4-c5 lever has been resolved the Bishop has done its job on e3 and White is ready to fight for control of d5.
moves.16... h6 17. Bh4 Rc8 18. Nf1: headed for e3, Tiviakov masses his forces on the fight for control of d5.
moves.18... Nb8: The knight is headed for d7.
moves.19. Ra3 Nbd7 20. Ne3 Qc7 21. Bb3 g6: Better was ...a5! when White would have only  a slight advantage.
moves.22. Nh2 Bg7 23. Qf3: White has control of d5 and if Black doesn't take decisive action White will tighten the screws with Nhg4.
moves.23... d5: ! best practical chance, passive defense would lose.
moves.24. Nxd5 Nxd5 25. Bxd5 Bxd5 26. exd5 Qd6: If 28.Nf1 f5 29.Nd2 f4 and the bishop is trapped.
moves.28... g5 29. Bg3 Red8: Black now wins back his pawn, but White retains the advantage.  If White can maneuver his knight to f5 he probably has a won game.
moves.30. Qe2 Qxd5 31. Rd1 Rc6: Tiviakov stated that an active defense was Black's best chance and recommended 31...e4.
White will now win material, and Tiviakov will keep control of the game until the end.
